chapter.title: The Shape Of Words To Come: Lojban Morphology

section.title: Introductory
section.para:
word formsin Lojban (see also morphology) morphologydefinition morphologysimplicity of Morphology is the part of grammar that deals with the form of words. Lojban's morphology is fairly simple compared to that of many languages, because Lojban words don't change form depending on how they are used. English has only a small number of such changes compared to languages like Russian, but it does have changes like boys as the plural of
boy, or walked as the past-tense form of walk. To make plurals or past tenses in Lojban, you add separate words to the sentence that express the number of boys, or the time when the walking was going on.

word formsas related to grammatical uses derivational morphologydefinition morphologyderivational However, Lojban does have what is called derivational morphology: the capability of building new words from old words. In addition, the form of words tells us something about their grammatical uses, and sometimes about the means by which they entered the language. Lojban has very orderly rules for the formation of words of various types, both the words that already exist and new words yet to be created by speakers and writers.

morphologyconventions for A stream of Lojban sounds can be uniquely broken up into its component words according to specific rules. These so-called morphology rules are summarized in this chapter. (A detailed algorithm for breaking sounds into words is part of the PEG grammar at the end of the book.) First, here are some conventions used to talk about groups of Lojban letters, including vowels and consonants.

Similarly, C/CC and C/CCC stand for longer clusters that straddle a syllable break.

section.para: brivlaas one of the 3 basic word classes cmevlaas one of the 3 basic word classes cmavoas one of the 3 basic word classes parts of speech word classes Lojban has three basic word classes – parts of speech – in contrast to the eight that are traditional in English. These three classes are called particles (cmavo), verbs (brivla), and name words (cmevla). Each of these classes has uniquely identifying properties – an arrangement of letters that allows the word to be uniquely and unambiguously recognized as a separate word in a string of Lojban, upon either reading or hearing, and as belonging to a specific word-class.

They are also functionally different: particles are the structure words, corresponding to English words like
and, if, the and to; verbs are the content words, corresponding to English words like come, red, doctor, and freely; name words correspond to English proper names like James, Afghanistan, and Pope John Paul II.

section.title: Particles
section.para: punctuation markscmavo as Lojban equivalents numberscmavo as Lojban equivalents prepositionscmavo as Lojban equivalents conjunctionscmavo as Lojban equivalents articlescmavo as Lojban equivalents structure words selma'odefinition cmavodefinition The first group of Lojban words discussed in this chapter are the particles. They are the structure words that hold the Lojban language together. They often have no semantic meaning in themselves, though they may affect the semantics of verbs or phrases to which they are attached. The particles include the equivalent of English articles, conjunctions, prepositions, numbers, and punctuation marks. There are over a hundred classes of particles, known as selma'o, each having a specifically defined grammatical usage. The various particle classes are discussed throughout to and summarized in .

cmavostructure of A particle is composed of a vowel or y, with optionally a consonant or glide before it and any number of 'V, 'VV, or 'y syllables after it. Here are some particles of various shapes:
In addition, there is the particle .ybu, the only one of its shape.

cmavolack of relation of form to grammatical use There are some conventions by which a particle's shape can hint at its grammar or meaning: for example, particles beginning with vowel letters are usually attitudinals. In general, though, the form of a particle tells you little or nothing about how it is used.

experimental cmavoforms for cmavofor experimental use All particles longer than two syllables, and most two-syllable particles containing diphthongs, are not officially defined and are reserved for experimental use. experimental cmavodefinition cmavoexperimental Experimental use means that the language designers have not assigned any standard meaning or usage to these words. Experimental particles provide an escape hatch for adding grammatical mechanisms (as opposed to semantic concepts) the need for which was not foreseen.

Particles of the form Cy, a consonant followed by the letter y, together with bu and .ybu, represent letters of the Lojban alphabet, and are discussed in detail in . Sequences of particles ending in y need to be separated from other words following them by a pause.

cmavo clusterscompared with sequence of simple cmavo compound cmavocompared with sequence of simple cmavo cmavo clustersdefinition compound cmavodefinition cmavocompound Particle clusters are sequences of particles attached together to form a single written word. Particles written together are always identical in meaning and in grammatical use to the corresponding space-separated sequence of particles. These words are written without spaces merely to save visual space, and to ease the reader's burden in identifying when the component words are acting together.
cmavo clustersrecognition of compound cmavorecognition of Particle clusters, while not visually short like their components, can be readily identified by two characteristics:

listitem.para: They have no consonant pairs or clusters, and
They end in a vowel.

section.title: Verbs
section.para: adverbsbrivla as Lojban equivalents verbsbrivla as Lojban equivalents adjectivesbrivla as Lojban equivalents nounsbrivla as Lojban equivalents brivladefinition Verbs or predicate words, called brivla, are at the core of Lojban. They carry most of the semantic information in the language. They serve as the equivalent of English nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs, all in a single part of speech.

subtypes of words types and subtypes of words Every verb belongs to one of three major subtypes. These subtypes are defined by the form, or morphology, of the word – all words of a particular structure can be assigned by sight or sound to a particular type (particle, verb, or name word) and subtype. Knowing the type and subtype then gives you, the reader or listener, significant clues to the meaning and the origin of the word, even if you have never heard the word before.

flexible vocabulary The same principle allows you, when speaking or writing, to invent new verbs for new concepts on the fly; yet it offers people that you are trying to communicate with a good chance to figure out your meaning. In this way, Lojban has a flexible vocabulary which can be expanded indefinitely.
brivlaproperties of All verbs have the following properties: they

listitem.para: always end in a vowel;
contain a consonant cluster, or start with a CVCy string;
and are always stressed on the next-to-the-last (penultimate) vowel; this implies that they have two or more syllables.

section.para: Note that these three conditions are not sufficient for a string of phonemes to be a valid verb. A complete specification can be found as part of the formal grammar in .
brivlasubtypes of The three subtypes of verbs are:

listitem.para: gismuas a subtype of brivla primitive rootsgismu as gismu, the Lojban primitive roots from which other verbs are built;
compound of gismulujvo as lujvoas a subtype of brivla lujvo, compounds of two or more gismu; and
zi'evlaas a subtype of brivla zi'evla, free words, the words that are not Lojban primitives or natural compounds, and are often borrowed from other languages.

section.title: Root words
section.para: gismurationale for choice of gismudefinition Lojban's root words, or gismu, are those verbs representing concepts most basic to the language. They were chosen for various reasons: some represent concepts that are very familiar and basic; some represent concepts that are frequently used in other languages; some were added because they would be helpful in constructing more complex words; some because they represent fundamental Lojban concepts (like cmavo and gismu themselves).

gismuas partitioning semantic space gismuselection of The root words do not represent any sort of systematic partitioning of semantic space. Some roots may be superfluous, or appear for historical reasons: the root list was being collected for almost 35 years and was only weeded out once. Instead, the intention was that the roots blanket semantic space: they make it possible to talk about the entire range of human concerns.

learning Lojbanmagnitude of task cmavo and gismumajor gismuand cmavomajor There are about 1350 root words. In learning Lojban, you need only to learn most of these as well as their combining forms (known as
rafsi) as well as perhaps 200 major particles, and you will be able to communicate effectively in the language. This may sound like a lot, but it is a small number compared to the vocabulary needed for similar communications in other languages.

gismulength of gismurules for Root words have very strong form restrictions. Using the conventions defined in , all roots are of the forms CCVCV, CVC/CV, or CVCCV. They must meet the rules for all verbs given in ; furthermore, they:

listitem.para: always have five letters;
always start with a consonant and end with a single vowel;
always contain exactly one consonant pair, which is a permissible initial pair (CC) if it's at the beginning of the word, but otherwise only has to be a permissible pair (CC or C/C);
are always stressed on the first syllable (since that is penultimate).

section.para: In addition, no root word contains ' or a diphthong.

gismuconflicts between gismuspecial With the exception of five special predicate variables, broda, brode, brodi, brodo, and brodu, no two roots differ only in the final vowel. Furthermore, the set of roots was specifically designed to reduce the likelihood that two similar sounding words could be confused. For example, because gismu is in the set of root words, kismu, xismu, gicmu, gizmu, and gisnu cannot be.

gismusource of Almost all Lojban root words are constructed from pieces of words drawn from other languages, specifically Chinese, English, Hindi, Spanish, Russian, and Arabic, the six most widely spoken natural languages. For a given concept, words in the six languages that represent that concept were written in Lojban phonetics. Then a word was selected to maximize the recognizability of the Lojban word for speakers of the six languages by weighting the inclusion of the sounds drawn from each language by the number of speakers of that language. See
for a full explanation of the algorithm.

section.title: Compound words
section.para: modifying brivla (see also seltau) seltaucompared with English adverb seltaucompared with English adjective tanruexplanation of When specifying a concept that is not found among existing verbs (or, more specifically, when the relevant word seems too general in meaning), a Lojbanist, when pressed for time, will generally attempt to express the concept as a tanru. In Lojban, any verb can be used to modify another verb. The first of the pair modifies the second. This modification is usually restrictive – the modifying verb reduces the broader sense of the modified one to form a more narrow, concrete, or specific concept. Modifying verbs may thus be seen as acting like English adverbs or adjectives. For example,
is the tanru which expresses the concept of computer user.

tanrucombination of The simplest Lojban tanru are pairings of two concepts or ideas. Such tanru take two simpler ideas that can be represented by single verbs and combine them into a single more complex idea. Two-part tanru may then be recombined in pairs with other tanru, or with individual verbs, to form more complex or more specific ideas, and so on.

tanruambiguity of The meaning of a tanru is usually at least partly ambiguous: skami pilno could refer to a computer that is a user, or to a user of computers. There are a variety of ways that the modifier component can be related to the modified component. It is also possible to use particles within tanru to provide variations (or to prevent ambiguities) of meaning.

tanruand creativity Making tanru is essentially a poetic or creative act, not a science. While the syntax expressing the grouping relationships within tanru is unambiguous, tanru are still semantically ambiguous, since the rules defining the relationships between the verbs are flexible. The process of devising a new tanru is dealt with in detail in .
tanruexpression of To express a simple tanru, simply say the component verbs together. Thus big boat becomes the tanru
representing roughly the same concept as the English word ship.

paternal grandmotherexample
Father mother can refer to a paternal grandmother (a father-ly type of mother), while mother father can refer to a maternal grandfather (a mother-ly type of father). In Lojban, these become the tanru
and
respectively.

tanruambiguity in The possibility of semantic ambiguity can easily be seen in the last case. To interpret , the listener must determine what type of motherliness pertains to the father being referred to. In an appropriate context, mamta patfu could mean not grandfather but simply father with some motherly attributes, depending on the culture. If absolute clarity is required, there are ways to expand upon and explain the exact interrelationship between the components; but such detail is usually not needed.

tanruto lujvo lujvofrom tanru brivlafrom tanru When a concept expressed in a tanru proves useful, or is frequently expressed, it is desirable to choose one of the possible meanings of the tanru and assign it to a new single word. For , we would probably choose user of computers, and form the new word
Such a verb, built from the rafsi which represent its component words, is called a compound or lujvo. Another example, corresponding to the tanru of , would be:

lujvoconstruction of rafsidefinition lujvounambiguous decomposition of The compound representing a given tanru is built from units representing the component root words. These units are called rafsi in Lojban. Each rafsi represents only one root. The rafsi are attached together in the order of the words in the tanru, occasionally inserting so-called hyphen letters to ensure that the pieces stick together as a single word and cannot accidentally be broken apart into smaller words. As a result, each compound can be readily and accurately recognized, allowing a listener to pick out the word from a string of spoken Lojban, and if necessary, unambiguously decompose the word to a unique source tanru, thus providing a strong clue to its meaning.
The compound that can be built from the tanru mamta patfu in is

which refers specifically to the concept maternal grandfather. The two root words that constitute the tanru are represented in mampa'u by the rafsi mam- and -pa'u, respectively; these two rafsi are then concatenated together to form mampa'u.

long rafsi formcompared with short form in effect on lujvo meaning short rafsi formcompared with long form in effect on lujvo meaning rafsi formeffect of choice on meaning of lujvo lujvomultiple forms of lujvomeaning of Like root words, compounds have only one meaning. When a compound word is formally entered into a dictionary of the language, a specific definition will be assigned based on one particular relationship between the terms. (See for how this has been done.) Unlike root words, compounds may have more than one form. This is because there is no difference in meaning between the various rafsi for a root when they are used to build a compound. A long rafsi may be used, especially in noisy environments, in place of a short rafsi; the result is equivalent to the version with short rafsi, even though the word is spelled and pronounced differently. Thus the word
brivla, built from the tanru bridi valsi, has the same definition as brivalsi, bridyvla, and bridyvalsi, each of which uses a different combination of rafsi.

apostropheand consonant cluster determination in lujvo ' symboland consonant cluster determination in lujvo y-hyphenand consonant cluster determination rafsirules for combining to form lujvo lujvorules for formation of When assembling rafsi together into compounds, the rules for valid verbs must be followed: a consonant cluster must occur before the second vowel (excluding those after an apostrophe), and the compound must end in a vowel.

glue in lujvoy-hyphen as y-hyphenand stress determination y-hyphenuse of A y (which is ignored in determining stress or consonant clusters) is inserted in the middle of the consonant cluster to glue the word together when the resulting cluster is either not permissible or the word is likely to break up. There are specific rules describing these conditions, detailed in

cmavocontrasted with same-form rafsi in meaning rafsicontrasted with same-form cmavo in meaning the rafsi soi- and -sai are joined, with the additional
r making up the rs consonant pair needed to keep the word together. Without the r, the word would break up into soi sai, two particles. The pair of particles have no relation to their rafsi lookalikes; they will either be ungrammatical (as in this case), or will express a different meaning from what was intended.
Learning rafsi and the rules for assembling them into compounds is clearly seen to be necessary for fully using the potential Lojban vocabulary.

lujvoinvention of Most important, it is possible to invent new compounds while you speak or write in order to represent a new or unfamiliar concept, one for which you do not know any existing Lojban word. As long as you follow the rules for building these compounds, there is a good chance that you will be understood without explanation.

section.title: rafsi
section.para: rafsiselection considerations in making lujvo gismulevel of uniqueness of rafsi relating to rafsilevel of uniqueness of relation to gismu rafsimultiplicity of for single gismu rafsiuniqueness in gismu referent of rafsiuse of Every root word has from two to five rafsi, each of a different form, but each such rafsi represents only one root. It is valid to use any of the rafsi forms in building compounds – whichever the reader or listener will most easily understand, or whichever is most pleasing – subject to the rules of compound making. There is a scoring algorithm which is intended to determine which of the possible and legal compound forms will be the standard dictionary form (see ).

unreduced lujvodefinition long rafsidefinition 4-letter rafsidefinition 5-letter rafsidefinition gismubasic rafsi for lujvounreduced rafsilong rafsiforms of Each root always has at least two rafsi forms; one is the root itself (used only at the end of a compound), and one is the root without its final vowel (used only at the beginning or middle of a compound). These forms are represented as CVCCV, CVC/CV or CCVCV (called the 5-letter rafsi), and CVCCy, CVC/Cy or CCVCy (called the 4-letter rafsi) respectively. The dashes in these rafsi form representations show where other rafsi may be attached to form a valid compound. When compounds are formed only from 4-letter and 5-letter rafsi, known collectively as
long rafsi, they are called
unreduced compounds.
Some examples of unreduced compound forms are:

lujvo-making.gloss: letter list or a list of letters

section.para: short rafsi rafsishort In addition to these two forms, each root may have up to three additional short rafsi, three letters long. All short rafsi have one of the forms CVC, CCV, CVV, or CV'V. The total number of rafsi forms that are assigned to a root depends on how useful the root is, or is presumed to be, in making compounds, when compared to other roots that could be assigned the rafsi.

-eruse of zmadu in forming comparativesuse of zmadu in forming For example, zmadu (more than) has the two short rafsi zma and mau (in addition to its unreduced rafsi
zmady and zmadu), because a vast number of compounds have been created based on zmadu, corresponding in general to English comparative adjectives ending in
-er such as whiter (Lojban labmau). On the other hand, bakri (chalk) has no short rafsi and few compounds.

There are at most one CVC-form, one CCV-form, and one CVV- or CV'V-form rafsi per root. In fact, only a tiny handful of roots have both a CCV-form and a CVV-form rafsi assigned, and still fewer have all three forms of short rafsi. However, roots with both a CVC-form and another short rafsi are fairly common, partly because more possible CVC-form rafsi exist. Yet CVC-form rafsi, even though they are fairly easy to remember, cannot be used at the end of a compound (because all verbs must end in vowels), so justifying the assignment of an additional short rafsi to many roots.

rafsirationale for assignments of rafsi space The intention was to use the available rafsi space- the set of all possible short rafsi forms – in the most efficient way possible; the goal is to make the most-used compounds as short as possible (thus maximizing the use of short rafsi), while keeping the rafsi very recognizable to anyone who knows the source roots. For this reason, the letters in a rafsi have always been chosen from among the five letters of the corresponding root. As a result, there are a limited set of short rafsi available for assignment to each root. At most seven possible short rafsi are available for consideration (of which at most three can be used, as explained above).

rafsiconsiderations restricting construction of There are a few restrictions: a CVV-form rafsi cannot exist unless the vowel letters make up one of the four diphthongs ai, ei, oi, or au; and a CCV-form rafsi is possible only if the two consonants form a permissible initial consonant pair (see ). mam is assigned to it.

numbersrafsi for rafsi for numbers Some particles also have associated rafsi, usually CVC-form. For example, the ten common numerical digits, which are all CV form particles, each have a CVC-form rafsi formed by adding a consonant to the particle. Most particles that have rafsi are ones used in composing tanru.

section.para: lujvorecognizing lujvo formnumber of letters in lujvo formconsonant cluster requirement in lujvo formfinal letter of lujvosummary of form characteristics As noted above, CVC-form rafsi cannot appear as the final rafsi in a compound, because all verbs must end with a vowel. As a verb, a compound must also contain a consonant cluster near the beginning – this ensures that they cannot be mistaken for particles. Of course, all compounds have at least six letters since they have two or more rafsi, each at least three letters long; hence they cannot be confused with roots.

lujvo formrequirements for hyphen insertion in hyphen letterdefinition hyphensuse of When attaching two rafsi together, it may be necessary to insert a hyphen letter. In Lojban, the term
hyphen always refers to a letter, either a y or one of the consonants r and n. (The letter l can also be a hyphen, but is not used as one in compounds.)

lujvo formrequirements for y-hyphen insertion in The y-hyphen is used after a CVC-form rafsi when joining it with the following rafsi could result in an impermissible consonant pair, or when the resulting compound could fall apart into two or more words (either particles or roots).

lujvoand consonant pairs Thus, the tanru pante tavla (protest talk) cannot produce the compound patta'a, because tt is not a permissible consonant pair; the compound must be patyta'a. Similarly, the tanru mudri siclu (wooden whistle) cannot form the compound mudsiclu; instead, mudysiclu must be used.

rafsifour-letterrequirement for y-hyphen The y-hyphen is also used to attach a 4-letter rafsi, formed by dropping the final vowel of a root, to the following rafsi. (This procedure was shown, but not explained, in to .)

The compound forms zunlyjamfu, zunlyjma, zuljamfu, and zuljma are all legitimate and equivalent forms made from the tanru zunle jamfu (left foot). Of these, zuljma is the preferred one since it is the shortest; it thus is likely to be the form listed in a Lojban dictionary.

lujvo formrequirements for n-hyphen insertion in lujvo formrequirements for r-hyphen insertion in r-hyphenuse of The r-hyphen and its close relative, the n-hyphen, are required in compounds starting with a CVV or CV'V rafsi. Without the hyphen, the first rafsi would fall off and be interpreted as a particle, leaving a shorter, but still valid word behind. The only exception is in compounds of the form CV[']V-CCV, which, there being no legal words of the shape CCV, can't possibly fall apart.

r-hyphencontrasted with n-hyphen in requirements for use n-hyphencontrasted with r-hyphen in requirements for use n-hyphenuse of An n-hyphen is only used in place of an r-hyphen when the following rafsi begins with r. For example, the tanru rokci renro (rock throw) cannot be expressed as ro'ire'o (which breaks up into two particles), nor can it be ro'irre'o (which has an impermissible double consonant); the n-hyphen is required, and the correct form of the hyphenated compound is ro'inre'o. The same compound could also be expressed without hyphenation as rokre'o.

R-hyphens (or n-hyphens before a rafsi beginning with r) are permitted, but not required, after CVV or CV'V rafsi in other positions. They may not occur after other kinds of rafsi or at the end of a word.

lujvowith zei There is also a different way of building compound words, or rather phrases which are grammatically and semantically equivalent to compounds. You can make a phrase containing any desired words, joining each pair of them with the special particle zei. Thus,

cmavo without rafsimethod of including in lujvo fu'ivlamethod of including in lujvo cmevlamethod of including in lujvo rafsilack ofeffect on forming lujvo lujvofrom cmavo with no rafsi is the exact equivalent of brivla (but not necessarily the same as the underlying tanru bridi valsi, which could have other meanings.) Using zei is the only way to get a particle lacking a rafsi, or a name word, into a compound:

lujvo-making.jbo: na'e zei .a zei na'e zei by. livgyterbilma

cmavocontrasted with rafsi in usage rafsicontrasted with cmavo in usage rafsicontrasted with words Note that rafsi may not be used in zei phrases, because they are not words. CVV and CV'V rafsi look like words (specifically particles) but there can be no confusion between the two uses of the same letters, because particles appear only as separate words; rafsi appear only as parts of compounds.

section.title: Free words
section.para:

The vast majority of words referring to plants, animals, foods, and scientific terminology cannot be easily expressed as tanru. They thus must be borrowed into Lojban from the original language.

One of these expedients is often quite sufficient when you need a word quickly in conversation. (This can make it easier to get by when you do not yet have full command of the Lojban vocabulary, provided you are talking to someone who will recognize the borrowing.)

fu'ivlaas Stage 3 borrowings borrowingsStage 3 borrowingsfu'ivla form with categorizing rafsi Where a little more universality is desired, the word to be borrowed must be Lojbanized into a full verb. A rafsi is often attached to the beginning of the Lojbanized form, using a hyphen to ensure that the resulting word doesn't fall apart.

borrowingsmost common form for fu'ivlauniqueness of meaning in rafsias fu'ivla categorizer fu'ivla categorizer The rafsi categorizes or limits the meaning of the loanword; otherwise a word having several different jargon meanings in other languages would require the word-inventor to choose which meaning should be assigned to the word, since Lojban words are not permitted to have more than one definition.

fu'ivlaas Stage 4 borrowings borrowingsStage 4 borrowingsfu'ivla form without categorizing rafsi Finally, Stage 4 borrowings do not have any rafsi classifier, and are used where a word has become so common or so important that it must be made as short as possible.

Stage 3 and 4 borrowings belong to a class of verbs that are not of root word shape and aren't compounds of roots either; words like this are called free words, or in Lojban, zi'evla. The form of a free word reliably distinguishes it from other word classes. In addition to the general criteria for Lojban verbs, free words:

listitem.para: slinku'i testdefinition must not be of root or compound word form; furthermore, a free word with a CV particle joined to the front of it must not have the form of a compound (the so-called slinku'i test, discussed further in );
yletterprohibition from fu'ivla cannot contain y, although they may contain syllabic pronunciations of Lojban consonants;

section.para: borrowingsStage 3 contrasted with Stage 4 in ease of construction fu'ivlacategorized contrasted with uncategorized in ease of construction This is a fairly liberal definition and allows quite a lot of possibilities within zi'evla space.

fu'ivlaform of fu'ivlaconstruction of Like cultural root words, borrowings are generally based on a word from a single non-Lojban language. The word is borrowed (actually copied, hence the Lojban term fu'ivla, from fukpi valsi) from the other language and Lojbanized – the phonemes are converted to their closest Lojban equivalent and modifications are made as necessary to make the word a legitimate Lojban word.

Stage 3 borrowings can be made easily on the fly, as compounds can, because the procedure for forming them always guarantees a word that cannot violate any of the rules. Stage 4 borrowings require running tests that are not simple to characterize or perform, and should be made only after deliberation and by someone knowledgeable about all the considerations that apply.
fu'ivlaalgorithm for constructing Here is a simple and reliable procedure for making a non-Lojban word into a valid Stage 3 borrowing:

listitem.para: Convert all sounds to their closest Lojban equivalents. Lojban y, however, may not be used in any free words.
Ensure that the sequence can be separated into valid Lojban syllables. Remove, for example, any invalid consonant clusters or sequences of vowels that aren't Lojban diphthongs.
If the last letter is not a vowel, modify the ending so that the word ends in a vowel, either by removing a final consonant or by adding a suggestively chosen final vowel.
If the first letter is not a consonant, modify the beginning so that the word begins with a consonant, either by removing an initial vowel or adding a suggestively chosen initial consonant.

fu'ivla categorizerselection consideration for l-hyphenuse of Prefix the result of steps 1-4 with a 4-letter or CVC-shaped rafsi that categorizes the word into a topic area. It is only safe to use a single 4-letter or CVC-form rafsi; other rafsi sometimes produce invalid words. Hyphenate the rafsi to the rest of the word with an r-hyphen; if that would produce a double r, use an n-hyphen instead; if the rafsi ends in r and the rest of the word begins with n (or vice versa), or if the rafsi ends in "r" and the rest of the word begins with "tc", "ts", "dj", or "dz" (using "n" would result in a phonotactically impermissible cluster), use an l-hyphen. (This is the only use of l-hyphen in Lojban.)
Remember that the stress necessarily appears on the penultimate (next-to-the-last) vowel.

section.title: Name words
section.para: names in Lojban (see also cmevla) cmevladefinition namespurpose of cmevlapurpose of Name words, or cmevla, are mostly used to import names, in other words, they are used to create labels applied to things (or people) to stand for them in descriptions or in direct address. They may convey meaning in themselves, but do not necessarily do so.

namesrationale for lojbanizing cmevlarationale for lojbanizing cmevlaand analyzability of speech stream namesexamples of cmevlaexamples of Because names are often highly personal and individual, Lojban attempts to allow native language names to be used with a minimum of modification. The requirement that the Lojban speech stream be unambiguously analyzable, however, means that most names must be modified somewhat when they are Lojbanized. A name may have multiple parts; these can be expressed as multiple words each ending with a consonant and surrounded by pauses, or the parts may be combined into a single word. For example,

namesauthority for cmevlaauthority for The final arbiter of the correct form of a name is the person doing the naming, although most cultures grant people the right to determine how they want their own name to be spelled and pronounced. The English name Mary can thus be Lojbanized as .meris., .maris., .meiris., .merix., or even .marys.. The last alternative is not pronounced much like its English equivalent, but may be desirable to someone who values spelling over pronunciation. section.title: Considerations for making compound words
section.para: Given a tanru which expresses an idea to be used frequently, it can be turned into a compound by following the compound-making algorithm which is given in .

In building a compound, the first step is to replace each root with a rafsi that uniquely represents that root. These rafsi are then attached together by fixed rules that allow the resulting compound to be recognized as a single word and to be analyzed in only one way.
There are three other complications; only one is serious.

rafsimultiple for each gismu The first is that there is usually more than one rafsi that can be used for each root. The one to be used is simply whichever one sounds or looks best to the speaker or writer. There are usually many valid combinations of possible rafsi. They all are equally valid, and all of them mean exactly the same thing. (The scoring algorithm given in is used to choose the standard form of the compound – the version which would be entered into a dictionary.)

linguistic drift in Lojbanpossible source of lujvoconsideration in choosing meaning for lujvounambiguity of The second complication is the serious one. Remember that a tanru is ambiguous – it has several possible meanings. A compound word, or at least one that would be put into the dictionary, has just a single meaning. Like a root word, a compound stands for a predicate which encompasses one area of the semantic universe, with one set of places. Hopefully the meaning chosen is the most useful of the possible semantic spaces. A possible source of linguistic drift in Lojban is that as Lojbanic society evolves, the concept that seems the most useful one may change.

lujvoultimate guideline for choice of meaning/place-structure The essential nature of human communication is that if the listener understands, then all is well. Let this be the ultimate guideline for choosing meanings and place structures for invented compounds.

lujvodropping elements of Zipf's Law The third complication is also simple, but tends to scare new Lojbanists with its implications. It is based on Zipf's Law, which says that the length of words is inversely proportional to their usage. The shortest words are those which are used more; the longest ones are used less. Conversely, commonly used concepts will be tend to be abbreviated. In English, we have abbreviations and acronyms and jargon, all of which represent complex ideas that are used often by small groups of people, so they shortened them to convey more information more rapidly.

Therefore, given a complicated tanru with grouping markers, abstraction markers, and other particles in it to make it syntactically unambiguous, the psychological basis of Zipf's Law may compel the compound-maker to drop some of the particles to make a shorter (technically incorrect) tanru, and then use that tanru to make the compound.

lujvobased on multiple tanru This doesn't lead to ambiguity, as it might seem to. A given compound still has exactly one meaning and place structure. It is just that more than one tanru is competing for the same compound. But more than one meaning for the tanru was already competing for the right to define the meaning of the compound. Someone has to use judgment in deciding which one meaning is to be chosen over the others.

lujvoshorter for more general concepts lujvoconsiderations for retaining elements of If the compound made by a shorter form of tanru is in use, or is likely to be useful for another meaning, the decider then retains one or more of the particles, preferably ones that set this meaning apart from the shorter form meaning that is used or anticipated. As a rule, therefore, the shorter compound will be used for a more general concept, possibly even instead of a more frequent word. If both words are needed, the simpler one should be shorter. It is easier to add a particle to clarify the meaning of the more complex term than it is to find a good alternate tanru for the simpler term.

lujvoand plausibility lujvoand the listener And of course, we have to consider the listener. On hearing an unknown word, the listener will decompose it and get a tanru that makes no sense or the wrong sense for the context. If the listener realizes that the grouping operators may have been dropped out, he or she may try alternate groupings, or try inserting an abstraction operator if that seems plausible. (The grouping of tanru is explained in ; abstraction is explained in .) Plausibility is the key to learning new ideas and to evaluating unfamiliar compounds.

section.title: The compound-making algorithm
section.para:
lujvoalgorithm for The following is the current algorithm for generating Lojban compound given a known tanru and a complete list of roots and their assigned rafsi. The algorithm was designed by Bob LeChevalier and Dr. James Cooke Brown for computer program implementation. It was modified in 1989 with the assistance of Nora LeChevalier, who detected a flaw in the original
tosmabru test.
Given a tanru that is to be made into a compound:

listitem.para: Choose a 3-letter or 4-letter rafsi for each of the roots and cmavo in the tanru except the last.
Choose a 3-letter (CVV-, CV'V-, or CCV-form) or 5-letter rafsi for the final root word in the tanru.
Join the resulting string of rafsi, initially without hyphens.
Add hyphen letters where necessary. Right-to-left tests are recommended, for reasons discussed below.

If there are more than two words in the tanru, put an r-hyphen (or an n-hyphen) after the first rafsi if it is CVV- or CV'V-form. If there are exactly two words, then put an r-hyphen (or an n-hyphen) between the two rafsi if the first rafsi is CVV- or CV'V-form, unless the second rafsi is CCV-form (for example, saicli requires no hyphen). Use an r-hyphen unless the letter after the hyphen is r, in which case use an n-hyphen. Never use an n-hyphen unless it is required.
Put a y-hyphen between the consonants of any impermissible consonant pair. This will always appear between rafsi.

Test all forms with one or more initial CVC-form rafsi – with the pattern CVC ... CVC + X – for tosmabru failure. X must either be a CVCCV long rafsi, one that has a permissible initial pair as the consonant cluster, or is something which has caused a y-hyphen to be installed between the previous CVC and itself by one of the above rules.
The test is as follows:
Examine all the C-C consonant pairs up to the first y-hyphen, or up to the end of the word in case there are no y-hyphens.
These consonant pairs are called "joints.

If all of those joints are permissible initials (CC rather than C/C), then the trial word will break up into a particle and a shorter verb. If not, the word will not break up, and no further hyphens are needed.
Install a y-hyphen at the first such joint.

section.para: lujvoselection of best form of lujvoscoring of Note that the tosmabru test implies that the algorithm will be more efficient if rafsi junctures are tested for required hyphens from right to left, instead of from left to right; when the test is required, it cannot be completed until hyphenation to the right has been determined.

section.title: The compound scoring algorithm
section.para: This algorithm was devised by Bob and Nora LeChevalier in 1989. It is not the only possible algorithm, but it usually gives a choice that people find preferable. The algorithm may be changed in the future. The lowest-scoring variant will usually be the dictionary form of the word. (In previous versions, it was the highest-scoring variant.)

listitem.para: Count the total number of letters, including hyphens and apostrophes; call it L.
Count the number of apostrophes; call it A.

Count the number of y-, r-, and n-hyphens; call it
H.

For each rafsi, find the value in the following table. Sum this value over all rafsi; call it R:
CVC/CV or CVCCV (final) (-sarji) 1
CVC/Cy or CVCCy (-sarj-) 2
CCVCV (final) (-zbasu) 3
CCVCy (-zbas-) 4
CVC (-nun-) 5
CV'V (-ta'u-) 6
CCV (-zba-) 7
CVV (-sai-) 8
Count the number of vowels, not including y; call it V.

section.para: lujvo formhierarchy of priorities for selection of hierarchy of priorities for selecting lujvo form The score is then: (1000 * L) - (500 * A) + (100 * H) - (10 * R) - V lujvoscored examples of In case of ties, there is no preference. This should be rare. Note that the algorithm essentially encodes a hierarchy of priorities: short words are preferred (counting apostrophes as half a letter), then words with fewer hyphens, words with more pleasing rafsi (this judgment is subjective), and finally words with more vowels are chosen. Each decision principle is applied in turn if the ones before it have failed to choose; it is possible that a lower-ranked principle might dominate a higher-ranked one if it is ten times better than the alternative.

section.para:
doghouseexample This section contains examples of making and scoring compound words. First, we will start with the tanru gerku zdani (dog house) and construct a compound meaning
doghouse, that is, a house where a dog lives. We will use a brute-force application of the algorithm in , using every possible rafsi.
The rafsi for gerku are:
The rafsi for zdani are:

Step 1 of the algorithm directs us to use -ger-, -ge'u- and -gerky- as possible rafsi for gerku; Step 2 directs us to use -zda- and -zdani as possible rafsi for zdani. The six possible forms of the compound are then:

We must then insert appropriate hyphens in each case. The first two forms need no hyphenation:
ge cannot fall off the front, because the following word would begin with rz, which is not a permissible initial consonant pair. So the compound forms are gerzda and gerzdani.

The third form, ge'u-zda, needs no hyphen, because even though the first rafsi is CVV, the second one is CCV, so there is a consonant cluster in the first five letters. So ge'uzda is this form of the compound.
The fourth form, ge'u-zdani, however, requires an r-hyphen; otherwise, the ge'u- part would fall off as a particle. So this form of the compound is ge'urzdani.

The last two forms require y-hyphens, as all 4-letter rafsi end in a y-hyphen, and so are
gerkyzda and gerkyzdani respectively.

The scoring algorithm is heavily weighted in favor of short compounds, so we might expect that gerzda would win. Its L score is 6, its A score is 0, its H score is 0, its R score is 12, and its V score is 3, for a final score of 5878. The other forms have scores of 7917, 6367, 9506, 8008, and 10047 respectively. Consequently, this compound would probably appear in the dictionary in the form gerzda.

section.title: The root word creation algorithm
section.para: source languagesuse in creating gismu The root words were created through the following process:

listitem.para: gismucreationscoring rules At least one word was found in each of the six source languages (Chinese, English, Hindi, Spanish, Russian, Arabic) corresponding to the proposed roots. This word was rendered into Lojban phonetics rather liberally: consonant clusters consisting of a stop and the corresponding fricative were simplified to just the fricative (tc became c, dj became j) and non-Lojban vowels were mapped onto Lojban ones. Furthermore, morphological endings were dropped. The same mapping rules were applied to all six languages for the sake of consistency.

All possible root word forms were matched against the six source-language forms. The matches were scored as follows:
If three or more letters were the same in the proposed Lojban root and the source-language word, and appeared in the same order, the score was equal to the number of letters that were the same. Intervening letters, if any, did not matter.
If exactly two letters were the same in the proposed Lojban root and the source-language word, and either the two letters were consecutive in both words, or were separated by a single letter in both words, the score was 2. Letters in reversed order got no score.
gismucreationconsiderations for selection after scoring Otherwise, the score was 0.

gismucreationproscribed gismu pairs gismutoo-similar The scores were divided by the length of the source-language word in its Lojbanized form, and then multiplied by a weighting value specific to each language, reflecting the proportional number of first-language and second-language speakers of the language. (Second-language speakers were reckoned at half their actual numbers.) The weights were chosen to sum to 1.00. The sum of the weighted scores was the total score for the proposed root word form.

Any forms that conflicted with existing words were removed. Obviously, being identical with an existing word constitutes a conflict. In addition, a proposed root that was identical to an existing word except for the final vowel was considered a conflict, since two such words would have identical 4-letter rafsi.

gismucreationand transcription blunders More subtly: If the proposed root was identical to an existing word except for a single consonant, and the consonant was "too similar based on the following table, then the proposed root was rejected.
gismusource-language weights for See for an example.

The word form with the highest score usually became the actual word. Sometimes a lower-scoring form was used to provide a better rafsi. A few words were changed in error as a result of transcription blunders (for example, the word gismu should have been gicmu, but it's too late to fix it now).

gismuLojban-specific Note that the stressed vowel of the root words was considered sufficiently distinctive that two or more roots may differ only in this vowel; as an extreme example,
bradi, bredi, bridi, and brodi (but fortunately not brudi) are all existing words.

section.title: Cultural and other non-algorithmic roots
section.para: The following words were not made by the root word creation algorithm. They are, in effect, loanwords. They are exceptions to the otherwise mandatory root creation algorithm where there was sufficient justification for such exceptions. Except for the small metric prefixes and the assignable predicates beginning with brod-, they all end in the letter o, which is otherwise a rare letter in Lojban root words.

gismuscientific-mathematical The following words represent concepts that are sufficiently unique to Lojban that they were either coined from combining forms of other roots, or else made up out of whole cloth. They are thus conceptually similar to compound words even though they are only five letters long; however, unlike compounds, they have rafsi assigned to them for use in building more complex compounds. Assigning roots to these concepts helps to keep the resulting compounds reasonably short.

It is important to understand that even though cmavo, lojbo, and lujvo were made up from parts of other roots, they are now full-fledged roots used in exactly the same way as all others, both in grammar and in word formation.

The following three groups of roots represent concepts drawn from the international language of science and mathematics. They are used for concepts that are represented in most languages by a root which is recognized internationally.

The other terms in this group are units in the international metric system; some metric units, however, were made by the ordinary process (usually because they are different in Chinese).

Finally, there are the cultural root words, which are also borrowed, but by modifying a word from one particular language, instead of using the multi-lingual root creation algorithm. Cultural root words are used for words that have local importance to a particular culture; other cultures or languages may have no word for the concept at all, or may borrow the word from its home culture, just as Lojban does. In such a case, the root word algorithm, which uses weighted averages, doesn't accurately represent the frequency of usage of the individual concept. Cultural roots are not even required to be based on the six major languages.

section.title: Including free words in compounds
section.para: The list of cultures represented by root words, given in , is unavoidably controversial. Much time has been spent debating whether this or that culture deserves a root word or must languish in free word space. To help defuse this argument, as the morphology was being codified into a formal grammar, a system was devised to give free words long rafsi, similar in concept to the four- and five-letter rafsi common to root words.
Each free word has itself as a final rafsi, hence:
To cope with the varied lengths of these words, the boundaries of free-word rafsi must be marked by y-hyphens:

tr.td: (a single free word, not necessarily related to cabna or dinsauru)

section.para: Free words starting with vowels also have rafsi, but they must be separated from preceding rafsi by an apostrophe so that the resulting word is phonotactically valid.
All free words also have non-final rafsi, similar to root words' four-letter rafsi, made by adding -'y to the end of the word.

Some shapes of free word, though by far not all, have shorter non-final rafsi made by replacing the final vowel with a y. Since the final vowel cannot be recovered from these rafsi, they should only be used when there are no similar words differing by only the final vowel.
To have such a rafsi, a free word must:

listitem.para: not have an apostrophe before its final vowel
when the final vowel is replaced with a y, not be segmentable into a string of shorter rafsi
when the final vowel is replaced with a y and the initial consonant removed, not be segmentable into a string of shorter rafsi

section.para: When these conditions are not met, the result is either a word made of other components than intended, or a non-word, a so-called slinku'i, as described in .
